citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A male peacock was seen limping on his left leg and was reluctant to walk. His foot appeared abnormal and one of the
toes sharply deviated to the side. The representative said someone donated it around 4/12/24 with a bad leg/foot and it
has been living with the goats but does fly to different areas of the park at times and has been eating and drinking. The
facility has not had this peacock’s leg/foot evaluated by the attending veterinarian (AV) to determine a treatment plan. Not
reporting an abnormal health condition to the AV can cause animal's condition to worsen or to be in discomfort. Animals
with abnormal health conditions or injury must be reported to the AV promptly so that they can receive veterinary care.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A lamb carcass was found by inspectors in the Dall sheep pasture barn (where the Dall sheep have been lambing); it was
seen to be decomposed and had maggots under it when the representative removed it from the barn. The representatives
did not know how long it had been there and said the barn isn't checked everyday. The decomposed state suggests that it
had been there days or longer. Thorough daily observations of animals and areas of housing must be completed so that
sick or dead animals can be promptly found and appropriate action can be taken when they are found.

The public barrier fence for the wolves had a gap between it and a trailer that public visitors could possible enter. A gap in
the barrier could allow the public to get too close to the wolves. Ensure that this gap is repaired to prevent public access
to this area.
-A public viewing area at the kangaroo pen was observed to have areas in panels where the inspector could have
reached in and contacted the male kangaroo that was by the fence. Public viewing areas that permit contact with
kangaroos could cause the kangaroos or public injury. Ensure to maintain a public barrier that prevents possible contact
with the kangaroos.
Correct both items by 4/25/2024.

The perch inside the shelter for the two macaques had a buildup of animal waste. The representative said that it is not
regularly cleaned but would be cleaned the same day of this inspection. A build-up of waste can make animals sick and
cause discomfort. Inside surfaces that non-human primates contact must be spot-cleaned daily. In addition, surfaces must
also be sanitized at least once every two weeks.

Some areas in animal enclosures were in need of repair:
-A panel between a young female tiger and the lion was observed to be rusted with sharp edges and loose at the bottom
when the tiger touched it and also later when the facility representative touched it after locking the lion out. A loose panel
with sharp edges could cause injury or allow two animals to contact each other and cause injury. Ensure that this panel is
repaired so that it is secure and protects the lion and tiger from possible injury.
-A piece of metal by one of the black bears' shelter entries was rusted and had sharp edges that bears could contact. Also
by the same entry there was a wire point exposed that bears could contact. Wire points and sharp rusted metal can cause
injury. Ensure these areas are repaired.
-There was a sharp point (an exposed screw) in the cougar's southwest corner shelter that the cougar could contact.
Sharp points can cause injury. Ensure that surfaces in the mountain lion's enclosure are free from sharp points.
Note: These were observed corrected prior to exit interview on 4/24/24. Ensure that all enclosures are maintained in a
manner that safely contains the animals and prevents injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A male peacock was seen limping on his left leg and was reluctant to walk. His foot appeared abnormal and one of the 
toes sharply deviated to the side. The representative said someone donated it around 4/12/24 with a bad leg/foot and it 
has been living with the goats but does fly to different areas of the park at times and has been eating and drinking. The 
facility has not had this peacock’s leg/foot evaluated by the attending veterinarian (AV) to determine a treatment plan. Not 
reporting an abnormal health condition to the AV can cause animal's condition to worsen or to be in discomfort. Animals 
with abnormal health conditions or injury must be reported to the AV promptly so that they can receive veterinary care. 
2.40(b)(3)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A lamb carcass was found by inspectors in the Dall sheep pasture barn (where the Dall sheep have been lambing); it was 
seen to be decomposed and had maggots under it when the representative removed it from the barn. The representatives 
did not know how long it had been there and said the barn isn't checked everyday. The decomposed state suggests that it 
had been there days or longer. Thorough daily observations of animals and areas of housing must be completed so that 
sick or dead animals can be promptly found and appropriate action can be taken when they are found. 
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The public barrier fence for the wolves had a gap between it and a trailer that public visitors could possible enter. A gap in 
the barrier could allow the public to get too close to the wolves. Ensure that this gap is repaired to prevent public access 
to this area.  
 
-A public viewing area at the kangaroo pen was observed to have areas in panels where the inspector could have 
reached in and contacted the male kangaroo that was by the fence. Public viewing areas that permit contact with 
kangaroos could cause the kangaroos or public injury. Ensure to maintain a public barrier that prevents possible contact 
with the kangaroos.  
 
Correct both items by 4/25/2024.

3.75(c)(3)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The perch inside the shelter for the two macaques had a buildup of animal waste. The representative said that it is not 
regularly cleaned but would be cleaned the same day of this inspection. A build-up of waste can make animals sick and 
cause discomfort. Inside surfaces that non-human primates contact must be spot-cleaned daily. In addition, surfaces must 
also be sanitized at least once every two weeks. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Some areas in animal enclosures were in need of repair: 
-A panel between a young female tiger and the lion was observed to be rusted with sharp edges and loose at the bottom 
when the tiger touched it and also later when the facility representative touched it after locking the lion out. A loose panel 
with sharp edges could cause injury or allow two animals to contact each other and cause injury. Ensure that this panel is 
repaired so that it is secure and protects the lion and tiger from possible injury.  
-A piece of metal by one of the black bears' shelter entries was rusted and had sharp edges that bears could contact. Also 
by the same entry there was a wire point exposed that bears could contact. Wire points and sharp rusted metal can cause 
injury. Ensure these areas are repaired.  
-There was a sharp point (an exposed screw) in the cougar's southwest corner shelter that the cougar could contact. 
Sharp points can cause injury. Ensure that surfaces in the mountain lion's enclosure are free from sharp points.  
 
Note: These were observed corrected prior to exit interview on 4/24/24. Ensure that all enclosures are maintained in a 
manner that safely contains the animals and prevents injury. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
